revision.text:
{{Infobox university |name = Russian-Armenian University |native_name = Российско-Армянский университет
Հայ-Ռուսական համալսարան |image_size = 250px |caption = Campus of the Russian-Armenian University (lower right) |latin_name = |motto = |established = 1997 |type = [[Public university|Public]] |endowment = |rector = [[Armen Darbinyan]] |undergrad = |postgrad = |doctoral = |address = |city = [[Yerevan]] |state = |country = [[Armenia]] |campus = |free_label = |free = |colours = |website = http://www.rau.am/ |logo = |footnotes = |image_name = Arargats&ArailerFromArabkir.jpg |staff = 700 |enrollment = 2,500 |profess = |affiliations = |publictransit = |telephone = |coor = }} '''Russian-Armenian University''' ('''RAU''') ({{lang-ru|Российско-Армянский университет}}, РАУ; {{lang-hy|Հայ-Ռուսական համալսարան}}) is an intergovernmental university being under the joint authority of the Russian Federation and Armenia. The university has a status of a higher educational institution in both states. The languages of instruction and communication at the university are [[Russian language|Russian]] and [[Armenian language|Armenian]].http://international.rau.am/eng/discoverRAU/historyoverview There are Russian and Armenian education sectors operating at RAU. Upon graduation, students receive two state Diplomas: Armenian and Russian. ==History== [[File:Սլավոնական համալսարան.JPG|thumb|left|The main building]] Russian-Armenian University was established following the inter-state agreement between Armenia and Russian Federation in 1997. In 1999, Academician Levon Mkrtchyan, Doctor of Philology, became university's first Rector. At present RAU Rector is former Prime-Minister of Armenia, Doctor of Economics, Professor, Corresponding Member of the National Academy of Sciences of Armenia, Armen Darbinyan, who assumed the post in 2001. The first students were enrolled in February 1999 in Law, Public and Municipal Administration and Journalism. Since then, the university has been constantly growing and encompassing new areas of education and research. Starting from 2002, scientific centers, institutions and problem research groups have been developing within the university. In the same year RAU opened a post-graduate course. In 2004 the reconstruction of the main building was finished, while in 2009 RAU opened its own Sports Complex. On October 15, 2004, the Park of Gratitude was opened on the university premises as a symbol of the Russian-Armenian friendship. This very day has become the day of RAU. On April 29, 2005 RAU was accredited by the Ministry of Education and Science of the Russian Federation.[http://international.rau.am/eng/discoverRAU/historyoverview] ==Institutes and Departments== ;Institute of Law and Politics [http://international.rau.am/eng/discoverRAU/institutes-departments] * Department of Constitutional Law and Municipal Law * Department of Political Science * Department of International Law and European Law * Department of Theory and History of Law and State * Department of Criminal Law and Criminal Procedure Law * Department of Civil Law and Civil Procedure Law * Department of World Politics and International Relations ;Institute of Mathematics and High Technology [http://international.rau.am/eng/discoverRAU/institutes-departments] * Department of Mathematics and Mathematical Modeling * Department of System Programming * Department of Mathematical Cybernetics * Department of Quantum and Optical Electronics * Department of General Physics and Quantum Nano-Structures * Department of Materials Technology and Structure of Electronic Technique * Department of Telecommunications * Department of Bioengineering, Bioinformatics and Molecular Biology * Department of General and Pharmaceutical Chemistry * Department of Medical Biochemistry and Biotechnology * Department of Microelectronic Schemes and Systems (jointly with "Synopsis Armenia" company) ;Institute of Economics and Business [http://international.rau.am/eng/discoverRAU/institutes-departments] *Department of Economic Theory and Challenges of Transition Economies *Department of Economics and Finance *Department of Management, Business and Tourism ;Institute of Humanities [http://international.rau.am/eng/discoverRAU/institutes-departments] *Department of Armenian Language and revision.text:
{{Tone|date=December 2007}} The '''Singapore Mathematical Olympiad''' ('''SMO''') is a mathematics competition organised by the [[Singapore Mathematical Society]]. It comprises three sections, Junior, Senior and Open, each of which is open to all pre-university students studying in Singapore who meet the age requirements for the particular section. The competition is held annually, and the first round of each section is usually held in late May or early June. The second round is usually held in late June or early July.
<!-- == History == == Eligibility == == Format of the Competition == -->
== Junior Section ==
The Junior Section consists of 5 multiple-choice questions, each with five options, and 20 open-ended questions, geared towards Lower Secondary students. Topics tested include number theory, calculus, pattern recognition, geometry, simple combinatorics and algebra. Noticeably, trigonometry is not included as a test subject, because trigonometry is not included in the Lower Secondary mathematical curriculum. Beginning in 2006, a second round was added, based on the Senior Invitational Round, and consists of a 6-question, 3hour long essay/proof.
== Senior Section ==
There are two rounds to the Senior Section: a written round (Round 1) and an invitational round (Round 2).
The exam in Round 1 consists of 5 multiple-choice questions, each with five options, and 20 open-ended questions. The Senior Test is geared towards Upper Secondary students, and topics tested include number theory, combinatorics, geometry, algebra, probability.
The second round, the Senior Invitational Round consists of a 5-question, 4-hour long paper, with each question of varying difficulty. Only the top scorers of Round 1 are invited to take this test, and helps determine the individual rankings of the test takers.
== Open Section ==
Similar to the Senior Section, there are also two rounds, the written round (Round 1) and the invitational round (Round 2).
The paper in Round 1 comprises 25 open-ended questions, and geared towards pre-university students. Topics tested include number theory, combinatorics, geometry, algebra, probability, but of a higher difficulty level than the Senior Section.
The Open Invitational Round consists of a 5-question, 4.5-hour long paper, in which only the top scorers of Round 1 are invited to take. This test will help determine the individual rankings of the scorers, and in addition, it acts as a guideline to select Singaporean or Permanent Resident participants for the National Team training team, whereby a further six will then be selected for the [[International Mathematical Olympiad]].
== Prizes ==
As of 2006, in each of the Junior and Senior sections, prizes are awarded to the 30 individuals with the highest total scores in the first and special rounds, as well as to the 20 [[secondary schools]] with the highest team scores. The team score is computed by summing the three best scores from students of their school in the first round alone. In the Open section, prizes are similarly awarded to the top 30 individuals, as well as to the 10 institutions (secondary schools and [[junior colleges]] with the highest team scores from the first round.
Effective 2012, however, school awards are also awarded based purely on the sum of the 3 highest scorers, including both the first and second round.
The above prizes take the form of cash awards, certificates displaying the individual's/team's ranking, as well as trophies. Individuals who do not place in the top 30 may also receive gold, silver, bronze, honourable mentions or participation, in decreasing order of merit. <!-- == Selection of the [[International Mathematical Olympiad]] Team == -->
== See also == * [[List of mathematics competitions]] * [[International Mathematics Olympiad]]
== External links == * [http://sms.math.nus.edu.sg/competitions/CompetitionHomePage.aspx Singapore Mathematical Society Competition Page]
[[Category:Education in Singapore]] [[Category:Mathematics competitions]]

revision.text:
The '''Texas Slavery Project''' is a [[digital history]] project created by Andrew J. Torget, currently Assistant Professor of History at the [[University of North Texas]]. It aims to explore the expansion of slavery between the years 1837 and 1845 in the lands in and around what would eventually become the state of Texas. It has been listed as among "the best and most important new work" in the developing digital history medium.<ref name=perspectives>{{Citation | last1 = Seefeldt | first1 = Douglas | last2 = Thomas | first2 = William G. | title = What is Digital History? A Look at Some Exemplar Projects | journal = Perspectives on History | volume = 47 | issue = 5 | pages = | publisher = American Historical Association | location = Washington, D.C. | date = May 2009 | url = http://www.historians.org/Perspectives/issues/2009/0905/0905for8.cfm | issn = 1556-8563 }}</ref> The project was presented at the 2007 Nebraska Digital Workshop held by the Center for Digital Research in the Humanities at the [[University of Nebraska–Lincoln|University of Nebraska-Lincoln]].
==Project Creation==
The initial creation of the [http://www.texasslaveryproject.org/ ''Texas Slavery Project''] arose from the needs of Andrew J. Torget while writing his doctoral dissertation examining the movement of American slaveholders and their slaves into Mexico during the 1820-1840s. Using the collection of tax information Torget assembled during his research, he created a database of population levels which was adapted into a digital [[MySQL]] format to allow greater control over the information contained in the database. Using the data from this new database, Torget then used [[GIS|Geospatial Information Systems]] (GIS) to visualize the spatial relations reflected in the population information which created highly complicated interactive maps.<ref name=abstract> {{Cite web |last = Torget |first = Andrew J. |title = Mapping the Borders of Slavery: The Texas Slavery Project |format = Abstract |publisher = Center for Digital Research in the Humanities |year = 2007 |url = http://cdrh.unl.edu/opportunities/neb_digital_workshop/archive.php |accessdate = October 27, 2009 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140510010115/http://cdrh.unl.edu/opportunities/neb_digital_workshop/archive.php |archivedate = May 10, 2014 |df = }} </ref> In an interview with the University of Nebraska-Lincoln's [http://digitalhistory.unl.edu/ ''Digital History''] website, Torget claimed that that use of these digital techniques provided for him "a microscope, of sorts, to look into the data that I already have in ways that, otherwise, I couldn't have done."<ref>{{Cite web|last=Torget |first=Andrew J. |title=Andrew Torget, University of Virginia |format=Interview |publisher=''Digital History'' |location=Lincoln, NE |year=2007 |url=http://digitalhistory.unl.edu/interviews.php#torget |accessdate=October 27, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090421202516/http://digitalhistory.unl.edu/interviews.php |archivedate=April 21, 2009 }}</ref>
In their examination of "exemplar" digital history projects in the May 2009 issue of the [[American Historical Society]]'s ''Perspectives on History'', historians Douglas Seefeldt and William G. Thomas heralded the ''Texas Slavery Project'' for its display of "how a digital project might extend, deepen, and launch interpretive aspects of a dissertation."<ref name=perspectives/>
==Project Overview==
According to the project's founder and director, Andrew J. Torget, the ''Texas Slavery Project'' endeavors to use digital technologies such as the MySQL database system and GIS mapping tools in order to analyze the spread of American slavery into the borderlands between Mexico and the United States. Through the use of digital maps, a database of historical population levels, and digitized primary source documents, the project examines the role of slavery in the development of the [[American Southwest]].<ref name=abstract/>
==Project Contents==
===Maps===
The maps contained within the project are, in fact, one decidedly interactive map for the years 1837-1845 which displays slave and slaveholder population statistics of the counties of Texas as well as various layers of data such as U.S. borders, regional rivers, a moveable timeline, and graphs displaying the rate of change in the population data. The information on the map can also be animated to see how the trends change over time. An additional feature graphs the information contained on the map and allows users to control the contents of the graph. The map and graph are in turn linked directly to the information in the database. For example, clicking on the outline of Nacogdoches County with the timeline demarking 1838 reveals the population information pertinent to Nacogdoches in 1838. This information is also provided by clicking on the point of the Nacogdoches county graph indicating 1838. "As a research and education tool this has the capacity to quickly show historical patterns and correlations that would otherwise have been extremely difficult to identify and illustrate."<ref>{{Citation | last1 = Arthur | first1 = Paul | title = Exhibiting History: the Digital Future | journal = reCollections: Journal of the National Museum of Australia. | volume = 3 | issue = 1 | pages = 33–50, 41 | publisher = | location = Canberra, Australia | date = March 2008 | url = http://recollections.nma.gov.au/ejournal_library/attachments/volume_3_number_1/exhibiting_history/files/27797/Exhibiting%20history.pdf | issn = 1833-4946 }}</ref>
===Database===
The project contains a searchable database of the population information compiled from Texas tax records. It is searchable by County or County Criteria, both of which allow the user to filter the search results as he or she chooses. The database contains information regarding the total slave population, total master population, masters with 1-4 slaves, masters with 5-9 slaves, masters with 10-19 slaves, masters with 20-49 slaves, masters with 50+ slaves, and the average slaveholding. The search results are downloadable in a text format. There are also a variety of graphs and statistics from data in the population database.
===Primary sources===
The project contains digitized copies of primary source documents from the 1820s through the 1840s. The documents are organized by the type of document: ''The Laws of Texas'', the Diplomatic Correspondence of the Republic of Texas, the James F. Perry Papers, the ''[[Telegraph & Texas Register]]'' of Houston, and the ''Civilian & Galveston Gazette''. The user has the option of browsing the documents or using the search engine.
==See also== * [[Digital history#Notable projects|Digital History- Notable Projects]] * [[Slavery in the United States]] *[[Ashworth Act]]
==References== <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.texasslaveryproject.org/ Texas Slavery Project] * [http://blog.historians.org/resources/887/slavery-in-america--online-resources "Slavery in America - Online Resources"] from ''AHA Today'' * [http://paulastuartwarren.blogspot.com/2009/01/texas-slavery-project.html Non-Academic Review of the Texas Slavery Project] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110726120309/http://www.oercommons.org/libraries/texas-slavery-project Texas Slavery Project] at [http://www.oercommons.org/ OER Commons]
[[Category:University of North Texas| ]] [[Category:Slavery in the United States]] [[Category:Digital history projects]] [[Category:Pre-emancipation African-American history]] [[Category:Digital humanities projects]]

{{Coord|35.569778|45.352163|display=title}} {{POV-lead|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox university |name = The American University of Iraq, Sulaimani |native_name = |image_name = AUIS Symbol.png |image_size = 220px |caption = |latin_name = |motto = Learn Today, Lead Tomorrow |mottoeng = |established = 2007 |closed = |type = [[Private University|Private]] |affiliation = |endowment = |chairman = [[Jill Derby]],http://auis.edu.krd/news/auis-board-trustees-elects-new-chair previously [[Barham Salih]] |chancellor = |president = [http://auis.edu.krd/president Bruce Ferguson] |superintendent = |provost = |vice_chancellor = |rector = |principal = |dean = |director = |head_label = |head = |faculty = 75 |staff = 201 |students = 1391{{cite web|title=About AUIS|url=http://auis.edu.krd/About|accessdate=11 February 2014}} |undergrad = |doctoral = |other = |city = [[Sulaymaniyah]] |state = |country = [[Iraq]] |coor = |campus = [[urban area|Urban]] 400 acres |former_names = |free_label = |free = |sports = [[Association football|Football (Soccer)]], [[Basketball]], [[Ping pong|Ping Pong]] |colors = {{Color box|#003262}} [[Blue (color)|Blue]]
{{Color box|#FDB515}} [[Gold (color)|Gold]] |nickname = AUIS |mascot = [[Eagle]] |athletics = AUIS Eagles - Soccer and Basketball |affiliations = |website = [http://auis.edu.krd/ auis.edu.krd] |logo = |footnotes = }} '''The American University of Iraq, Sulaimani''' ('''AUIS''') is a [[not-for-profit]], [[Private University|private institution]] for public benefit, located in the cultural capital of [[Iraqi Kurdistan]], [[Sulaymaniyah|Sulaimani]].{{cite web |url=http://www.amicalnet.org/about/members/american-university-iraq-sulaimani |title=American University of Iraq in Sulaimani |author= |publisher=Amical Consortium |accessdate=April 17, 2013}}{{Dead link|date=May 2017|fix-attempted=yes}} The University offers an American-style liberal arts education to students from various economic, ethnic and religious backgrounds. Since its founding in 2007, the University has been committed to producing knowledgeable and skilled graduates.AUIS.[http://auis.edu.krd/node/1088 2015.Mission & Core Values.] Accessed 4 feb 2015.{{third-party inline|date=May 2017}} The University opened its doors in 2007 to 45 students from across [[Iraq]]. By the end of its second year, the university had 256 enrolled students, 20 of which were in the MBA program.Jane Arraf, [http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2008/1208/p01s02-wome.html "University brings American-style learning to Iraq"], ''The Christian Science Monitor'', December 8, 2008. Accessed 4 February 2015.{{Failed verification|date=May 2017}} Today, AUIS provides undergraduates with instruction in humanities, social sciences, natural sciences, information technology, business and engineering. The language of instruction at AUIS is exclusively English. Students with low English scores are required to complete the Academic Preparatory Program, where they improve their English language skills and learn critical thinking, before entering the undergraduate programs.{{third-party inline|date=May 2017}} {{Failed verification|date=May 2017}} ==History== The American University of Iraq, Sulaimani was founded in 2006 by a Board of Trustees who set out to establish an institution dedicated to offering a comprehensive, American-style education in Iraq. The University, modeled after the famous private universities in Cairo and Beirut, was created amid the turmoils of war but in the relatively secure Kurdish region of Iraq. The purpose of founding such a university, according to Dr. [[Barham Salih]] was to stimulate reform in the Iraqi education system. Its location, however, was contested by Arab education officials in Baghdad who argued that the university should be built there and not in a region with historically secessionist ambitions.Edward Wong, [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/03/world/middleeast/03university.html "An American University for Iraq but Not in Baghdad."] The New York Times, January 3, 2007. Accessed 4 February 2015. Intellectuals such as [[Kanan Makiya]], [[Fouad Ajami]] and [[John Agresto]], many of whom supported the 2003 American invasion, supported the establishment of AUIS. John Agresto went on to become the University’s Acting Chancellor for a brief interregnum, after serving as a Coalition Provisional Authority Senior Advisor to the [[Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research (Iraq)|Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research]] in Baghdad. Joshua Mitchell, professor of political theory at [[Georgetown University]] became Acting Chancellor in 2008 and remained in his position for two years while on leave from Georgetown.[http://explore.georgetown.edu/people/mitchelj/ Joshua Mitchell], Georgetown University, People. Accessed 4 February 2015. From 2010 to 2013, [[Athanasios Moulakis]] served as Acting President and he continues to hold the title of President Emeritus of the University. In May 2013, the Board of Trustees chose [[Dawn Dekle]] as president. She became the first female president of an Iraqi university when she took up her position at AUIS. She ended her tenure at AUIS in November 2014 due to family circumstances.AUIS. [http://auis.edu.krd/node/1470 Dr. Dawn Dekle Ends Her Tenure as President of AUIS.] Accessed 4 February 2015. Esther Mulnix was chosen to serve as interim president after Dekle’s departure.AUIS, [http://auis.edu.krd/mulnix_bio Dr. Esther Mulnix.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905110920/http://auis.edu.krd/mulnix_bio |date=2015-09-05 }} Accessed 4 February 2015. ==Campus== The main campus has 169-hectares of land situated on the Sulaimani-Kirkuk Road, close to the [[University of Sulaymaniyah]]. Construction of the campus was completed at the start of the academic year in 2011. The campus has several buildings, including an administrative building with a multipurpose auditorium, an academic building, a state-of-the-art science labs, a gym, male and female dormitories, as well as two basketball courts and one soccer field. The AUIS library is located in the academic building while its cafeteria is housed in the administrative building. AUIS is currently located just outside the city limits of [[Sulaimani]].{{cite web |url=http://auisvoice.org/node/285 |title=New campus sounds promising to (01) AUI-S students with all academic equipments, labs |date=May 19, 2011 |author=Kurdistan Fatih |publisher=AUIS Voice |accessdate=April 17, 2013}} The AUIS academic building opened in October 2011 while its administrative building opened in the spring semester of 2012.{{cite web |url=http://www.agbsearch.com/sites/agbsearch.civicactions.net/files/AUIS%20Pres-Profile-Final-011613.pdf |title=THE AMERICAN UNIVERSITY OF IRAQ,SULAIMANI - The Search for a President |author= |publisher=AGB Research |accessdate=April 17, 2013 }}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Moreover, the new student dorm facilities opened in November 2012.{{cite web|title=Housing|url=http://www.auis.edu.krd/housing|accessdate=16 December 2012}} ==Former campus== AUIS was first located in a temporary campus in the heart of [[Sulaimani]]. The campus consisted of about 50 temporary classrooms and offices built near a main administrative building, which housed the university's cafeteria, library, and several large classrooms. As of 2012, the former campus is an admission campus. ==Organization== The University has a Board of Trustees composed of prominent Iraqi and American leaders from across a wide range of sectors, including government, business, nonprofit and education sectors. The Board of Trustees oversees the management and operations of the University and is a self-perpetuating body that establishes it policies.AUIS, [http://auis.edu.krd/board_of_trustees Board of Trustees.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905110818/http://auis.edu.krd/board_of_trustees |date=2015-09-05 }} Accessed 4 February 2015. ==Academia== ===Academic Preparatory Program=== The Academic Preparatory Program (APP) prepares non-native English speaking high school graduates to undertake undergraduate studies at AUIS. In addition to English Language skills, they teach critical thinking and study habits. The APP ensures that students have the necessary proficiency in English reading, speaking and writing along with awareness of academic cultural norms and expectations to succeed in their undergraduates studies at AUIS.AUIS, [http://auis.edu.krd/app Academic Preparatory Program.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905113953/http://auis.edu.krd/app |date=2015-09-05 }} Accessed 4 Feb 2015. ===Undergraduate Program=== The Undergraduate program at AUIS is modeled after the liberal American-style of education and includes seven different majors. AUIS undergraduates explore different disciplines before choosing a major. The six different departments at AUIS include the Department of Business Administration, Engineering, English and Journalism, Information Technology, Social Sciences and Mathematics and Natural Sciences. Students also have the option of pursuing a secondary course of study in addition to their degree program.AUIS, [http://auis.edu.krd/undergrad_academics Undergraduate Programs.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905113639/http://auis.edu.krd/undergrad_academics |date=2015-09-05 }} Accessed 4 Feb 2015. All instruction at AUIS is in [[English language|English]], and all language instructors are native English speakers.{{cite web |url=http://www.ekurd.net/mismas/articles/misc2012/1/state5842.htm |title=English Degree to Start at American University of Iraq, Sulaimani (AUIS) Fall 2012 |date=January 31, 2012 |author=Bzhar Ali Boskani |publisher=Kurd Net |accessdate=April 17, 2013}} ===Graduate programs=== AUIS offers an [[MBA]] program through its Business and Administration Department. ==Professional Development Institute== The Professional Development Institute (PDI) complements the educational objectives of the American University of Iraq, Sulaimani by providing opportunities for lifelong learning through programs and services that enables participants to develop the knowledge and skills necessary to achieve personal and professional goals, improve the productivity of organizations, and provide leadership and service to their communities.Investingroup, [http://www.investingroup.org/interview/167/ Interview, "Educational Edge"], 27/08/2014. Accessed 4 Feb 2015. PDI is a certified Cisco Academy and is accredited by the Association of Chartered Certified Account, the Project Management Institute and ICDL. PDI has also been certified as a PMI Registered Education Provider.AUIS, [http://auis.edu.krd/professional_development_institute Professional Development Institute.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150909083403/http://auis.edu.krd/professional_development_institute |date=2015-09-09 }} Accessed 4 Feb 2015. ==Student Life and Culture== AUIS provides a thriving and vibrant culture of extracurricular activities and sports on campus. Students can take part in many activities including drama, debate, linguistics, music, athletics, social work and indoor games like chess. There are several clubs and societies as well as sports and athletic teams for both men and women at AUIS. Throughout the year, these clubs and societies arrange events and meet to engage more students in creative, extracurricular initiatives.AUIS, [http://auis.edu.krd/activities_athletics Student Organizations.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905113913/http://auis.edu.krd/activities_athletics |date=2015-09-05 }} Accessed 4 Feb 2015. The University frequently takes part in arranging cultural events outside the campus as well. In 2013, the Drama Club and English Department joined forces to hold The Art of Social Justice - a one-week festival celebrating creative arts. The festival, backed by the [[US State Department]], hosted performances, workshops, discussions and field trips by renowned American and Iraqi artists. Later, AUIS senior lecturer Marie Labrosse published a book, SoJust, that chronicled the arts festival in Sulaimani.Alana Marie Levinson-Labrosse, [http://www.fairobserver.com/region/middle_east_north_africa/iraqi-american-encounters-the-art-of-social-justice-01246/ "Iraqi-American Encounters: The Art of Social Justice."] ''Fair Observer''. Accessed 4 Feb 2015. The University has also held events and performances at important cultural landmarks like the Cultural Cafe and Chai Xana Sha’ab, in keeping with the strong traditions of the cultural capital of Kurdistan. It has also held various poetry recitations, like the Poetry Slam,AUIS, [http://auis.edu.krd/Poerty_Slam Poetry Slam.]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Accessed 5 Feb 2015. and the poetry workshop at [[Koc University]] in [[Istanbul]].{{Citation needed|date=April 2016}} AUIS students are generally very active in volunteer and social work. They have led several charity drives, cook-offs, and international donation initiatives to help the displaced persons and refugees from Iraq and Syria, in partnership with organisations like Kurdistan [[Save the Children]]. Most of these initiatives are led by students independently. Startup Weekend SlemaniStartup Weekend, [http://www.up.co/communities/iraq/slemani/startup-weekend/3843 Startup Weekend Slemani.] Accessed 5 Feb 2015. is another independent initiative, pioneered predominantly by a group of talented AUIS alumni. The popular event brings together professionals and young entrepreneurs to encourage startup companies and businesses in Kurdistan. ===Clubs and Societies=== Several clubs and societies at AUIS allow students with similar interests to mingle with each other, and hone their extracurricular skills. The student organisations vary from developing professional skills like IT and business; to creative arts like anime, drama, music, debate, and literature; to indoor games like chess; as well as sports, hiking and cycling. The AUIS drama club produces plays and dramas throughout the year. Some of their productions include “[[Twelve Angry Men (play)|Twelve Angry (Wo)men]]”,AUIS. [http://auis.edu.krd/node/1468 AUIS Drama Presents Twelve Angry (Wo)men.] Accessed 5 Feb 2015. “[[Noor (play)|Noor]]”, “Will’s Cafe”AUIS. [http://auis.edu.krd/node/1329 AUIS Celebrates Shakespeare's 450th Birthday.] Accessed 5 Feb 2015. - a play to celebrate Shakespeare's 450th birthday; and “The Arranged” - a commentary on the tradition of arranged marriages also written by a student Mahdi Murad,AUIS. [http://auis.edu.krd/node/693 AUIS Students Debut Akbar Ahmed's "Noor".] Accessed 5 Feb 2015. and “[[9 Parts of Desire (play)|9 Parts of Desire]]” - performed during the Art of Social Justice Festival focussing on Iraqi migrant women. In December 2015, two AUIS students, Leah Farooq and Beyan Tahir, were selected to participate in the Home Grown program - an intensive theatrical training provided jointly by the Kevin Spacey Foundation and The Middle East Theatre Academy. The students were part of a troupe of 35 talented young people scouted from all over the Middle East for the workshop. Both participants selected from Iraq were students at AUIS. The workshop culminated in a theatrical performance in Sharjah on January 25, 2015.[http://www.middleeasttheatreacademy.org/ Middle East Theatre Academy.] Accessed on 5 Feb 2015. [[Kevin Spacey]] trained the students and watched their performance in Sharjah.Afshan Ahmed. [http://www.thenational.ae/arts-lifestyle/on-stage/kevin-spacey-skips-sag-awards-to-watch-his-arab-students-perform-in-sharjah "Kevin Spacey skips SAG awards to watch his Arab students perform in Sharjah."] The National. January 26, 2015. Accessed 5 Feb 2015. AUIS also hosts the offices of the first independent, English language, student newspaper in Iraq, The AUIS Voice. The AUIS Voice is run by an editorial board composed solely of students, and is published biweekly. The Washington Post included two pictures of the AUIS Voice staff in a photo collection titled “Youths in Iraq: The War Generation.”The Washington Post. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/youths-in-iraq-the-war-generation/2011/11/25/gIQAR86GzN_gallery.html World: "Youths in Iraq: The war generation".] Accessed 5 Feb 15. AUIS Voice is also a member of the Associated Collegiate Press. The editorial board selects new editors in the beginning of the fall semester, and the paper is regularly published throughout the fall and spring semester.AUIS Voice. [http://www.auisvoice.com/About%20Us About Us] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150205100518/http://www.auisvoice.com/About%20Us |date=2015-02-05 }}. Accessed 5 Feb 2015. ===Athletics=== Student at AUIS, both men and women, are able to be active in sports. The University has two basketball courts and one football field on campus. The official mascot for the athletics teams is the Eagle, and the teams include men’s and women’s basketball and football, ping-pong or table tennis, and tai chi. The teams play intercollegiate as well as intramural matches at AUIS, and have also been on international tours. Students on both the women’s and men’s basketball team at AUIS participated in the 34th Annual Sports Fest at [[Boğaziçi Üniversitesi]] in 2014.AUIS. [http://auis.edu.krd/node/1373 AUIS Basketball Teams Compete at Boğaziçi Üniversitesi Sports Fest.] Accessed 5 Feb 2015. In 2011, a documentary made by an American film company gained international recognition for the women’s basketball team. The film [[Salaam Dunk]] was shown at several international film festivals including Chicago International film festival and Los Angeles film festival.[http://salaamdunkfilm.com/ Salaam Dunk.] Accessed 5 Feb 2015. ==Institute of Regional and International Studies== AUIS houses Sulaimani’s independent research centre, the Institute of Regional and International Studies (IRIS). The centre focuses on the local, regional, and international, social and political issues through research, scholarships, debate and conferences. According to the university website, the institute “examines the region’s most complex issues through rigorous scholarship, advanced research, and open dialogue among academic and influential public leaders.”AUIS. [http://auis.edu.krd/IRIS Institute of Regional and International Studies.] Accessed 5 Feb 2015. The centre conducts meetings, round-tables, conferences and lectures on topics pertinent to the local and regional politics. It invites leading figures from the government, political parties, businesses, historical and cultural institutions to have meaningful dialogues on issues and challenges pertinent to the region. Housed in a tolerant and diverse institution, IRIS provides a neutral space for open and critical dialogue on challenging topics. The centre runs one of the most strategic conferences, the Sulaimani Forum, which has rapidly gained recognition throughout the region. Christine van den Toorn became IRIS Director in 2015. She writes for local and international publications and is frequently quoted and interviewed about local and regional issues in Kurdistan and Iraq in [[Al-Jazeera]],Sofia Barbarani. [http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/06/iraq-yazidis-caught-crossfire-201462412464507378.html Iraq's Yazidis: Caught in the crossfire."], ''Al Jazeera''. Accessed 5 Feb 2015. [[The Daily Beast]],The Daily Beast. [http://www.thedailybeast.com/contributors/christine-van-der-toorn.html "Christine Van Den Toorn".] Accessed 5 Feb 2015. the podcast Iraq MattersIraq Matters 2014, Episode ten (Feb, 2014), [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N1yOTSQWnno "Is Peace in Iraq Possible? The Story of 'Little Iraq'"] and Musings on Iraq.Musings On Iraq. Iraq News, Politics, Economics, Society. [http://musingsoniraq.blogspot.com/2014/09/the-plight-of-iraqs-yazidis-in-ninewa.html "The Plight of Iraq's Yazidis in Ninewa Province Interview with Christine van den Toorn"], September 1, 2014. Accessed 5 Feb 2015. She is the director and founder of The Primary Source, which provides research and reporting services to the KRG and wider Iraq.The Primary Source. [http://www.theprimarysourceiraq.com/ On-the-Ground Research in Iraq and the Kurdistan Region of Iraq] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150205102348/http://www.theprimarysourceiraq.com/ |date=2015-02-05 }}. Accessed 5 Feb 2015. ===Sulaimani Forum=== The Institute of Regional and International Studies (IRIS) at AUIS organises an annual forum to open dialogue and debate on the challenging regional political issues concerning the Middle East. The Sulaimani Forum is held in March/April every year and focuses on the most pressing local and regional issues through in-depth panel discussions and debates.[http://sulaimaniforum.com/sulaimaniforum2015/ Sulaimani Forum.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150516051841/http://sulaimaniforum.com/sulaimaniforum2015/ |date=2015-05-16 }} Accessed 5 Feb 2015. The forum invites prominent speakers and specialists on the topic from both within Iraq, the wider region and Europe and the United States. The forum is covered extensively by the local and international media. During the inaugural Forum in 2013, the event trended on Twitter with #SulaimaniForum in Egypt and Iraq.[http://cloud.snappages.com/db139e142aed7611bb5b31ed4679c1592eba4e82/Sulaimani%20Forum%202013.pdf "The Inaugural Sulaimani Forum"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150205100015/http://cloud.snappages.com/db139e142aed7611bb5b31ed4679c1592eba4e82/Sulaimani%20Forum%202013.pdf |date=2015-02-05 }}. ''cloud.snappages.com''. Accessed 5 Feb 2015. The hashtag #suliforum created quite a buzz on Twitter during the second Sulaimani Forum in 2014.Twitter. AUIS [https://twitter.com/auis_news/status/440777007949819906 @AUIS_NEWS.] Accessed 5 Feb 2015. The first Sulaimani Forum, in March 2013 held at AUIS, explored the changing dynamics of the Middle East. The forum created a very open debate on issues such as Iraq’s internal and external relations, oil, security, Kurdistan and the Arab Spring, etc. The speakers and panelists included distinguished names such as [[Hoshyar Zebari]], [[Zalmay Khalilzad]], and [[Max Rodenbeck]] among others. “For an Iraqi Kurd and someone who has attended many such events around the world, the Sulaimani Forum provided the most relevant discussions on Iraq, its politics and future” reviewed Kurdish journalist and commentator [[Hiwa Osman]] on his blog.[http://hiwaosman.com/2013/03/in-the-back-rows-of-the-sulaimani-forum-a-hint-of-iraqs-future/ "Thoughts from Iraq: A page that completes the Iraqi story".] Accessed 5 Feb 2015. The second Sulaimani Forum, “Navigating Challenges in the Middle East” brought together experts from around the region on 4–5 March 2014. The list of speakers included [[Nechirvan Barzani]], Prime Minister of the KRG, who gave a speech at the forum.Gulan Media. [http://www.gulan-media.com/english/details.php?section=1&id=5730 "Premier Barzani: Kurdistan will 'Not Back Down' Over Constitutional Oil Rights'".] Accessed 5 Feb 2015. Others included Hoshyar Zebari, [[Ahmet Davutoğlu]], Zalmay Khalilzad, Falah Al Fayad and [[Bernard Kouchner]]. This forum was also covered extensively by several media and publications.AUIS. [http://auis.edu.krd/PRsuliforum2014 AUIS Hosts Second Annual Sulaimani Forum, PM Nechirvan Barazani Keynotes.]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Accessed 5 Feb 2015. “While its unofficial epithet, The Davos of the Middle East, may be ambitious, the 2014 Sulaimani Forum, hosted by the American University of Iraq, Sulaimani (AUIS) on March 4th and 5th, was not far off the mark—especially considering that this year’s annual Forum was only the second of its kind.” reviewed the Invest In Group, covering the highlights of the Forum.Invest In Group. [http://www.investingroup.org/briefing/155/ "Investor Highlights from the Sulaimani Forum]". Accessed 5 Feb 2015. The third annual Sulaimani Forum was hosted at AUIS on 11–12 March 2015. The 2016 forum was held in Iraqi Kurdistan.Wright, Robin, [http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/how-the-curse-of-sykes-picot-still-haunts-the-middle-east "How the Curse of Sykes-Picot Still Haunts the Middle East"], ''[[The New Yorker]]'', April 30, 2016. Retrieved 2016-04-30. ===IRIS Fellowship=== The Institute provides grants and assistance to visiting faculty to pursue research projects pertinent to the region. The fellows are provided research grants as well as research assistance by their students. Most visiting fellows are encouraged to teach courses relevant to the research as well. The 2014-15 fellows include Maria Fantappie, Maria Saldarriaga, and Vanessa Iaria.AUIS. [http://auis.edu.krd/iris_fellows Fellows]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. Accessed 5 Feb 2015. Fantappie was a visiting scholar at the [[Carnegie Middle East Centre]] in Beirut,Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. [http://carnegieendowment.org/experts/?fa=expert_view&expert_id=580 "Maria Fantappie".] Accessed 5 Feb 2015. has worked for the [[International Crisis Group]] in Iraq, and is considered a specialist on Kurdish issues.[http://info.arte.tv/en/maria-fantappie-specialist-kurdish-issues "Refugees- An in-depth look at camps".] ''info.arte.tv''. Accessed 5 feb 2015. She has written extensively, on the Kurdish issues and Iraq’s domestic political challenges. In March 2014, she was interviewed for ‘Inside the Middle East’ Q&A series hosted by the [[Belfer Center]]. She has published several reports on Iraq, Syria, and the rising issue of the Kurds in the region for the International Crisis Group.International Crisis Group. [http://www.crisisgroup.org/~/media/Files/Middle%20East%20North%20Africa/Iraq%20Syria%20Lebanon/Iraq/144-make-or-break-iraq-s-sunnis-and-the-state "Make or Break: Iraq's Sunnis and the State."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160202091207/http://www.crisisgroup.org/~/media/Files/Middle%20East%20North%20Africa/Iraq%20Syria%20Lebanon/Iraq/144-make-or-break-iraq-s-sunnis-and-the-state |date=2016-02-02 }} Accessed 5 feb 2015.International Crisis Group. [http://www.crisisgroup.org/~/media/Files/Middle%20East%20North%20Africa/Iraq%20Syria%20Lebanon/Syria/136-syrias-kurds-a-struggle-within-a-struggle.pdf "Syria's Kurds: A Struggle within a Struggle."] Accessed 5 Feb 2015. Her research at AUIS focuses on the Kurdish youth and their relationship with the traditional Kurdish political parties. One of the 2013-14 IRIS fellows is Bilal Wahab - a lecturer of social sciences at AUIS, and a commentator on issues related to Kurdistan, including oil and energy policies in Iraq.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9FLQHMmUVdw Kurdistan: The American Lens - Bilal A. Wahab Full Interview.] Accessed 5 Feb 2015. As part of his fellowship, Dr. Wahab published on Iraq and KRG’s energy policies.[http://auis.edu.krd/sites/default/files/WahabIRISReport.pdf Iraq and KRG Energy Policies: Actors, Challenges and Opportunities.] Accessed 5 Feb 2015. His interviews and quotes appear frequently in Invest In Group,Invest In Group. [http://www.investingroup.org/interview/164/ "Changing Dynamics". Interview.] 24.08.2014. Accessed 5 Feb 2015. [[Rudaw]],Yerevan Saeed. [http://rudaw.net/mobile/english/middleeast/iraq/18122014 "Amid Iraq war, Basra autonomy bid gaining greater support."] 18.12.2014. Accessed 5 feb 2015. [[NPR]]NPR. [https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=9462859 "Kurdistan Feels Pressure of Iraqi Influx."] 04.08.2007. Accessed 5 feb 2015. and PUKMedia,PUKMedia. [http://www.pukmedia.com/EN/EN_Direje.aspx?Jimare=22781 "ISIL weakens from its conflict over energy fields."] Accessed 5 Feb 2015. etc. He has appeared as a panelist in a discussion on national reconciliation prospects in Iraq and Syria at the [[Johns Hopkins University]] in Washington.[http://webcast.jhu.edu/Mediasite/Play/a38e2a90ab8f4e7f8b9c673ae223b6571d National Reconciliation and Negotiation.] Accessed 5 Feb 2015. IRIS fellow, Maria Saldarriaga, is conducting her research on traditional water sources (karez) and the sustainable management of groundwater resources in Iraq and Kurdistan. At the same time, she is teaching a special course on water in Iraq, including “history, water resources, traditional water systems, quality, in addition to the current challenges.”AUIS. [http://auis.edu.krd/waterinIraq Studying Water in Iraq.]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Accessed 5 Feb 2015. ===IRIS Publications=== IRIS has published the analyses and summaries of the first and the second annual Sulaimani Forum, as well as the report on energy policies by Bilal Wahab.AUIS. [http://auis.edu.krd/iris_publications IRIS Publications.]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Accessed 5 feb 2015. ==Criticism== In 2009, ''[[CounterPunch]]'' ran an article by former English instructor Mark Grueter who stated that the university functioned more as a political tool than as an educational institution.Grueter, Mark, [http://www.counterpunch.org/2009/11/06/inside-the-american-university-of-iraq/ Inside the American University of Iraq], ''[[CounterPunch]]'' (November 2009) Faculty members and students have complained about mismanagement and incompetence. In 2010, ''[[AlterNet]]'' ran an article by former English instructor John Dolan which affirmed Grueter's viewpoint and detailed the university's connections to [[Donald Rumsfeld]] via [[John Agresto]].Dolan, John, [http://www.alternet.org/story/148443/i_was_a_professor_at_the_horribly_corrupt_american_university_of_iraq..._until_the_neocons_fired_me I Was a Professor at the Horribly Corrupt [American University of Iraq]... Until the Neocons Fired Me, ''[[AlterNet]]'' (October 2010) In 2011, [[Salon.com]] noted the university's link to President [[George W. Bush]] through [[Donald Rumsfeld]] protegee, [[John Agresto]], who was then serving as AUIS's Provost. {{cite web | last = Baker | first = Russ | first2 = Kristina |last2=Borjesson |first3=Mark |last3=Grueter | title = The empire strikes again | publisher = Salon | url = http://www.salon.com/2011/02/16/american_university_iraq/ | date = 16 February 2011 | accessdate = 17 February 2011}} ==See also== {{Portal|Iraq|Kurdistan|United States|University}} * [[Private Universities in Iraq]] * ''[[Salaam Dunk]]'', 2011 documentary about the university's women basketball program *[[AUC Press]] *[[Cairo International Model United Nations]] *[[American University of Sharjah]] (AUS) *[[American University of Beirut]] (AUB) *[[American University in Dubai]] (AUD) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://auis.edu.krd/] . *[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/03/world/middleeast/03university.html?ex=1325480400&en=d5a54dbf5aac32e6&ei=5088 "An American University for Iraq but Not in Baghdad"] ''The New York Times'', January 3, 2007 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110428172640/http://www.counterpunch.org/greuter11062009.html "Inside the American University of Iraq"] by Mark Grueter in ''[[CounterPunch]]'', November 6–8, 2009 *[http://www.alternet.org/world/148443/i_was_a_professor_at_the_horribly_corrupt_american_university_of_iraq..._until_the_neocons_fired_me?page=entire "I Was a Professor at the Horribly Corrupt American University of Iraq...Until the Neocons Fired Me"] by [[John Dolan (writer)|John Dolan]] in ''[[Alternet]]'' October 8, 2010 *[http://www.salon.com/news/iraq/index.html?story=/politics/war_room/2011/02/16/american_university_iraq The empire strikes again], ''[[Salon.com]]'', February 16, 2011 {{DEFAULTSORT:American University Of Iraq - Sulaimani}} [[Category:Sulaymaniyah]] [[Category:Universities in Iraqi Kurdistan]] [[Category:Private universities and colleges]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 2007]] [[Category:2007 establishments in Iraqi Kurdistan]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 0 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9) ([[User:Smasongarrison|Smasongarrison]])
revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{notability|Products|date=January 2011}} {{COI|date=November 2011}} }}
'''TrendTopper MediaBuzz College Guide''' is an American-college guide based on what it calls "Internet brand equity" based on Internet data, social media, blogs and the top 75,000 print and electronic media outlets. It ranks what it calls the Top 300 United States colleges and universities. The guide includes specialty and for profit schools including Art, Business, Design, Music, and Online Education. The TrendTopper MediaBuzz College Rankings are produced twice a year by the [[Global Language Monitor]] of [[Austin]], [[Texas]].
== College brand equity== The TrendTopper MediaBuzz College Rankings are produced twice a year by the [[Global Language Monitor]]. GLM describes their rankings as measuring the Internet “Brand Equity” of the colleges and universities. [[Time Magazine]] described internet brand equity as "a measure of who's talking about you online, based on Internet data, social media, blogs and the top 75,000 print and electronic media outlets.<ref>[http://newsfeed.time.com/2011/01/05/the-most-buzzed-about-university-wisconsin/ The Most Buzzed-About University?]</ref><ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/12/30/us-universities-topbrands-idUSTRE6BT41J20101230/ Harvard, Yale Beaten]</ref> GLM ranks the schools "according to their online presence -- or internet brand equity ... By focusing on online presence, the Monitor hopes to avoid the biases that characterize other rankings, which commonly rely on the opinions of university officials and college counselors rather than that of the greater public.<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/01/10/buzzworthy-schools-which-_n_806809.html#s221586&title=University_of_WisconsinMadison/ The Most Buzz Worthy Schools]</ref>" GLM believes the rankings provide an up-to-date perspective on which schools have the most popular brand. for example, it cites the Ivy League University of Pennsylvania (ranked fifth in 2010 by U.S. News) fared almost equivalently to Penn State (ranked 47th in 2010 by U.S. News), ranking 22nd and 24th respectively." <ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/01/10/buzzworthy-schools-which-_n_806809.html#s221586&title=University_of_WisconsinMadison/ Buzzworthy Schools]</ref> The resulting tool, the group claims, gauges the relative value of the various institutions and how they change over time.
== Inclusion of specialty schools== The rankings are the only ones that contain specialty schools which are typically assigned to "unranked" or "other' categories. "The rankings include specialty (and for profit) schools as well, such as Art, Business, Design,<ref>http://www.pratt.edu/admissions/request_information/facts_and_figures/ Pratt Rankings</ref> Music, and even Online Education. Most specialty schools are included in the College category with the exception of the online university, which is assigned to the University category ... The MediaBuzz list also compiles the Best of Class (BOC) from among all, the designation being awarded to those schools that are first in terms of brand repute and impact, either in the overall ranking or in a specific classification, such as Top Catholic College<ref>[http://www.HolyCross.edu/ Holy Cross]</ref> or University.<ref>[http://www.georgetown.edu./ Georgetown]</ref><ref>[http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/96516/20101231/harvard-chicago-university-rankings-brand.htm Wisconsin Beats Harvard in Brand Equity]</ref>"
The TrendTopper MediaBuzz Analysis uses the [[Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching]]’s classifications as the basis to distinguish between Universities and Liberal Arts Colleges. The schools were ranked in the last week of December with a mid-year snapshot, and the last day of 2009 as the base.
GLM claims that TrendTopper MediaBuzz utilizes a mathematical model that ‘normalizes’ the data collected from the Internet, social media, and blogosphere as well as the top 75,000 print and electronic media and that the end result is a non-biased analytical tool that provides a gauge of relative values among various institutions, as well as measures of how that value changes over time. The basics of the methodology are available for download directly from the Global Language Monitor site.<ref>[http://www.languagemonitor.com]</ref>
==Criticism== TrendTopper MediaBuzz uses narrative tracking technology, where the words, phrases and concepts are tracked in relation to their frequency, contextual usage and appearance in global media outlets. This exclusive ranking is based upon GLM's Narrative Tracking technology. NarrativeTracker analyzes the Internet, blogosphere, the 75,000 print and electronic media, as well as new social media sources (such as Twitter). NarrativeTracker replaced the controversial PQI index, which had been criticized by a number of linguists, but no media tracking, or computer scientists or other members of the academic community, for its use in the counting of the number of English words.<ref>[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyID=5390581 Enumerating English],</ref>
The Global Language Monitor also sells the TrendTopper MediaBuzz Reputation Management solution for higher education for which "colleges and universities can enhance their standings among peers".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.languagemonitor.com/about/trendtopper/trendtopper-enhances-college-reputation | title=TrendTopper enhances college reputation | publisher=Global Language Monitor | accessdate=2009-11-03}}</ref> The Global Language Monitor states that it "does not influence the Higher Education rankings in any way".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.languagemonitor.com/college_rankings |title=College Rankings |publisher=[[The Global Language Monitor]] }}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref>
==Comparisons to other rankings== Milwaukee Magazine stated that "a study by Kiplinger’s that buttresses Global Language Monitor’s findings, researchers conclude that UW-Madison is one of the best values in higher education. The study ranked schools based on academic caliber – graduation and retention rates, student-to-teacher ratios and the SAT and ACT scores of incoming students – and affordability".<ref>[http://www.milwaukeenewsbuzz.com/?p=412645 Brand power]{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Comparisons are frequently made between the TrendTopper MediaBuzz College rankings and the ''[[Princeton Review]]'' and the [[U.S. News & World Report]] College and University rankings, which suggest that "a brand equity service based on ''buzz'' is certainly important, and reflects a more democratic perspective. It is a good contender against rankings posted by U.S. News & World Report or The Princeton Review.<ref>[http://thefosburyflop.com/2011/01/07/edu-brand-equity/ Ed-BrandEquity]</ref> However, there are others who question the value of using brand equity studies with higher education.<ref>[http://www.mediabistro.com/agencyspy/university-of-wisconsin-1-in-internet-brand-equity_b12361 Wisconsin No. 1 in Internet Brand Equity]</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Trendtopper Mediabuzz College Guide}} [[Category:University and college rankings]]

Jacques | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1956|7|24|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Dorking]], [[Surrey]], [[England]] | residence = [[Toronto|Toronto, Ontario]], [[Canada]] | nationality = [[British people|British]] and [[Canadians|Canadian]] | ethnicity = | education = [[Bachelor of Science|B.Sc.]], A.R.C.S., GradInstP | alma_mater = [[Royal College of Science]], [[Imperial College]] | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | occupation = [[Information technology consulting|IT consultant]], [[author]], [[Sexology|sex researcher]], and [[Sex education|sex educator]] | years_active = 1979 — present | employer = | organization = Associate of the [[Royal College of Science]]
Graduate of the [[Institute of Physics]]
Member of the [[Royal College of Science Association]] | known_for = [[Sex education]] and advocacy | notable_works = ''On The Safe Edge'' (1993)
''Alternate Sources'' (1996)
''Gay Guide Canada'' (1997)
''Canada's Gay Guide'' (1998, 1999) | influences = | influenced = | movement = | spouse = | children = | parents = | relatives = | awards = Pantheon of Leather award, Canadian Region (1994, 1997) | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | website = [http://TrevorJacques.com/ TrevorJacques.com] | footnotes = }} '''Trevor H. Jacques''' (born 24 July 1956) is a [[Canadian]] [[author]], [[activist]], [[sex researcher]], and [[IT consultant]] based in [[Toronto|Toronto, Ontario]], Canada. His research and writing are in the area of consensual [[BDSM]], [[sexual fetishism]] and [[sexual health]]. He is also a [[Switch (BDSM)|BDSM switch]]. Jacques is best known for two notable sex books: ''On The Safe Edge: A Manual for SM Play''{{cite book|last=Jacques|first=Trevor|title=On The Safe Edge: A Manual for SM Play, leatherbound edition|year=1993|publisher=WholeSM Publishing|location=Toronto|isbn=1895857058|pages=352|url=http://WholeSM.com/OTSEExtracts.html|edition=First|author2=Dr. Dale |author3=Hamilton, Michael |author4= Sniffer |accessdate=6 May 2012}}{{cite book|last=Jacques|first=Trevor|title=On The Safe Edge: A Manual for SM Play, hardcover edition|year=1993|publisher=WholeSM Publishing|location=Toronto|isbn=1895857066|pages=352|url=http://WholeSM.com/OTSEExtracts.html|edition=First|author2=Dr. Dale |author3=Hamilton, Michael |author4= Sniffer |accessdate=6 May 2012}}{{cite book|last=Jacques|first=Trevor|title=On The Safe Edge: A Manual for SM Play, paperback edition|year=1993|publisher=WholeSM Publishing|location=Toronto|isbn=1895857066|pages=352|url=http://WholeSM.com/OTSEExtracts.html|edition=First|author2=Dr. Dale |author3=Hamilton, Michael |author4= Sniffer |accessdate=6 May 2012}}{{cite book|last=Jacques|first=Trevor|title=On The Safe Edge: A Manual for SM Play, ebook|year=1993|publisher=WholeSM Publishing|location=Toronto|isbn=9781895857160|pages=352|url=http://WholeSM.com/OTSEExtracts.html|edition=First|author2=Dr. Dale |author3=Hamilton, Michael |author4= Sniffer |accessdate=6 May 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://LeatherArchives.org/exhibits/deblase/timeline2.htm#1993 |title=Leather History Timeline, 1993 |publisher=Leather Archives and Museum |accessdate=7 May 2012}} and ''Alternate Sources''.{{cite book|last=Jacques|first=Trevor|title=Alternate Sources, paperback|year=1996|publisher=WholeSM Publishing|location=Toronto|isbn=1895857090|issn=1201-2823|pages=480|url=http://WholeSM.com/ASInfo.html|edition=First|accessdate=6 May 2012}}{{cite book|last=Jacques|first=Trevor|title=Alternate Sources, CD-ROM|year=1996|publisher=WholeSM Publishing|location=Toronto|isbn=1895857155|pages=|url=http://WholeSM.com/ASInfo.html|edition=First|accessdate=6 May 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://LeatherArchives.org/exhibits/deblase/timeline2.htm#1996 |title=Leather History Timeline, 1996 |publisher=Leather Archives and Museum |accessdate=7 May 2012}} ==Biography== Jacques attended [[St Joseph's College, Ipswich|St. Joseph's College]], Birkfield, Ipswich, a school run by the [[Institute of the Brothers of the Christian Schools|De La Salle brothers]], from 1967 to 1974. He earned his degree in [[Physics]] from the [[Imperial College London|Imperial College of Science and Technology]] in 1978, thereby becoming an associate of the [[Royal College of Science]] (A.R.C.S.) and graduate the [[Institute of Physics]] (GradInstP.). From 1979, he worked for Seismograph Service Ltd. as a field seismologist off the coast of the [[French Congo]] and [[Gabon]] and in [[England]], for two and a half years, before designing the acceptance test specifications and procedure for the missile management system of a European aircraft for Computing Devices Company, in [[Hastings]], [[East Sussex]]. In 1981, he emigrated to Toronto to work at [[Spar Aerospace]] for nine years on an infrared surveillance system for the Canadian and U.S. navies. Subsequently, he moved to SmartStar and Orapro (database companies) in Toronto, as head of technical support and then director of consulting. He was CIO at [[Stott Pilates]] (now Merrithew Health and Fitness) for three years (1998-2001), and continues to provide IT consulting to the company. ===Later=== He co-founded Toronto’s Safer SM Education seminar series in 1991, along with co-authors of ''On The Safe Edge'', Dr. Dale McCarthy (1937-2007, co-founder of the AIDS Committee of Toronto (ACT)), Michael Hamilton, and Sniffer (the latter being a dentist and teacher at the [[University of Toronto]]), and both organised and presented the seminars for thirteen years (1991-2004). The seminars led to both the publication of ''On The Safe Edge'' and updated versions of ''Safer SM'' (a BDSM safer sex pamphlet published by the AIDS Committee of Toronto).{{cite web |url=http://SexResearch.ca/SSSS/PDFs/SaferSM5-PanelPamphlet19951115.pdf |title=Safer SM, 1995 |publisher=The AIDS Committee of Toronto |accessdate=7 May 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://sexresearch.ca/SSSS/PDFs/SaferSM6-PanelPamphlet19991011.pdf |title=Safer SM, 1999 |publisher=The AIDS Committee of Toronto |accessdate=7 May 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://orders.catie.ca/product_info.php?products_id=25523 |title=BDSM: Safer Kinky Sex, 1996, 2009, 2010 |publisher=The AIDS Committee of Toronto |accessdate=7 May 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://orders.catie.ca/product_info.php?products_id=25838 |title=BDSM: Jeux 'kinky' plus sécuritaires, 2011 |publisher=The AIDS Committee of Toronto |accessdate=7 May 2012}} Jacques edited and published ''Gay Guide Canada''{{cite book|last=Jacques|first=Trevor|title=Gay Guide Canada|year=1997|publisher=Gay Guide Canada, Inc.|location=Toronto|isbn=1-894076-00-1|pages=176|url=http://GayGuideCanada.com/CGGPages/CGGInfo.lasso|edition=First|accessdate=6 May 2012}}, 1997, and ''Canada's Gay Guide'', 1998{{cite book|last=Jacques|first=Trevor|title=Canada's Gay Guide|year=1998|publisher=Click & Drag|location=Toronto|isbn=1-894076-02-8|pages=176|url=http://GayGuideCanada.com/CGGPages/CGGInfo.lasso|edition=First|accessdate=6 May 2012}} and 1999.{{cite book|last=Jacques|first=Trevor|title=Canada's Gay Guide|year=1999|publisher=Click & Drag|location=Toronto|isbn=1-894076-04-4|pages=208|url=http://GayGuideCanada.com/CGGPages/CGGInfo.lasso|edition=First|accessdate=6 May 2012}} He also sponsored the production and printing Toronto’s ''Pride Guide'' in 1996,{{cite book|last=Jacques|first=Trevor|title=Pride Guide '96|year=1996|edition=1996|author2=Pride Toronto |publisher=Alternate Sources, WholeSM Publishing|location=Toronto|isbn=1-895857-13-9|issn=1205-8017|pages=98|url=http://PrideToronto.com/|accessdate=18 Dec 2013}} 1997,{{cite book|title=Pride Guide '97|year=1997|edition=1997|author=Pride Toronto|publisher=Pride Toronto|location=Toronto|isbn=|issn=1205-8017|pages=36|url=http://PrideToronto.com/|accessdate=18 Dec 2013}} and 1998 {{cite book|title=Pride Guide '98|year=1998|edition=1998|author=Pride Toronto|publisher=Pride Toronto|location=Toronto|isbn=|issn=1205-8017|pages=36|url=http://PrideToronto.com/|accessdate=18 Dec 2013}} on behalf of [[Pride Toronto]]. In 2001{{cite book|last=Jacques|first=Trevor|title=Mr. Leatherman Toronto Souvenir Guide|year=2001|edition=2001|author2=Adkin, David |author3=Gowans, Doug |publisher=Mr. Leatherman Toronto Competition, Inc.|location=Toronto|isbn=|issn=1499-5417|pages=56|url=http://TorontoLeatherPride.ca/|accessdate=6 May 2012}} and 2002,{{cite book|last=Jacques|first=Trevor|title=Mr. Leatherman Toronto Souvenir Guide|year=2002|edition=2002|author2=Adkin, David |publisher=Mr. Leatherman Toronto Competition, Inc.|location=Toronto|isbn=|issn=1499-5417|pages=64|url=http://TorontoLeatherPride.ca/data/forms/MrLTSouvenirGuide2003.pdf|accessdate=6 May 2012}} he edited and published the souvenir guide for the Mr. Leatherman Toronto Competition. Jacques has contributed articles, interviews, and expert advice to dozens of magazines, newspapers, and radio and television stations in North America and Europe. Jacques served as an expert witness in the 1998 "[[Terri-Jean Bedford|Bondage Bungalow]]" case in north Toronto. ''On The Safe Edge'' was cited in the submissions by the BDSM community in London, England to the [[Law Commission (England and Wales)|Law Commission]] as it prepared its report "Consent in the Criminal Law" (consultation paper 139), as a result of the [[Operation Spanner|Spanner case]]. In 2009, Jacques was featured in the fourth Canadian edition of the sexuality textbook ''Understanding Human Sexuality''.[http://www.mcgrawhill.ca/highereducation/products/0070764107/ ''Understanding Human Sexuality''], In Focus 15.2, pp. 476-477. {{ISBN|9780070764101}}, {{ISBN|0070764107}} Jacques’s most recent publication is ''BDSM: Safer Kinky Sex'', in both English and French, for the AIDS Committee of Toronto. It is the third major revision of a safer sex education pamphlet created and edited by the Toronto BDSM community, this time large enough to take the form of a booklet. He also edited the two variants of the previous version (see References). Jacques was invited by ACT to launch the French version in Montréal, in May, 2011. ==Awards and recognition== * Pantheon of Leather Award, Canadian region, 1994.{{cite web |url=http://LeatherArchives.org/exhibits/deblase/timeline2.htm#1994 |title=Leather History Timeline, 1994 |publisher=Leather Archives and Museum |accessdate=7 May 2012}} * Honorary Board Member of the Leather Archives and Museum, 1996. * Pantheon of Leather Award, Canadian region, 1997.{{cite web |url=http://LeatherArchives.org/exhibits/deblase/timeline2.htm#1997 |title=Leather History Timeline, 1997 |publisher=Leather Archives and Museum |accessdate=7 May 2012}} * Mr. Leatherman Toronto Competition Francis Robichaud Memorial award for consistent significant contributions to Toronto’s gay and lesbian community, 2001 * AIDS Committee of Toronto, 10 years outstanding service, 2002 ==Conferences== * Guelph Sexuality Conference, [[University of Guelph]], Ontario, 1997. Poster session.{{cite book |author=Jacques, Trevor |title=Distribution of visitors to a Kinky Sex Website |publisher= |location= |year=1997 |pages=8 |isbn= |url= |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}} * [[American Association of Sexuality Educators, Counselors and Therapists|Association of American Sex Educators, Counselors, and Therapists]]/[[Society for the Scientific Study of Sexuality]] (AASECT/SSSS), [[St. Louis]], [[Missouri]], 1999. Presentation.{{cite book |author1=Bienvenu, Robert |author2=Jacques, Trevor |title=Patterns of Development and Practice in Today's BDSM Subcultures: Results from a Survey of SM Practitioners |publisher= |location= |year=1999 |pages=68 |isbn= |url=http://SexResearch.ca/SSSS/PDFs/AASECTSSSSJacquesBienvenu99.pdf |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=6 May 2012}} * [[International Academy of Sex Research]] (IASR), Annual Meeting, [[Paris]], 2000. Presentation.{{cite book |author1=Fedoroff, J. Paul |author2=Jacques, Trevor |title=BDSM Internet Web "Masters": Gender and Sexual Orientation effects on the internet sex survey responses of self-proclaimed sadomasochists |publisher= |location= |year=2000 |pages=2 |isbn= |url=http://SexResearch.ca/SSSS/PDFs/IASR_2000_Fedoroff_Jacques.pdf |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=6 May 2012}} * Society for the Scientific Study of Sexuality (SSSS), [[Montréal]], [[Québec]], 8 November 2002. Presentation.{{cite book |author1=Bienvenu, Robert |author2=McGeorge, H. Jack |author3=Jacques, Trevor |title=The General Psychological Health of SM Practitioners|publisher= |location= |year=2002 |pages=29 |isbn= |url=http://SexResearch.ca/SSSS/PDFs/SSSS_2002_B_McG_Jacques.pdf |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=6 May 2012}}{{cite book |author1=Bienvenu, Robert |author2=McGeorge, H. Jack |author3=Jacques, Trevor |author4=Fedoroff, J. Paul |title=An Anonymous Survey Of Self-Identified BDSM Practitioners Using The GHQ |publisher= |location= |year=2003 |pages=2 |isbn= |url=http://SexResearch.ca/SSSS/PDFs/IASR_2003_B_McG_Jacques.pdf |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=6 May 2012}} * International Academy of Sex Research (IASR), Annual Meeting, [[Bloomington, Indiana|Bloomington]], [[Indiana]], 2003. Presentation.{{cite book |author1=Fedoroff, J. Paul |author2=Jacques, Trevor |author3=Curry, Susan |author4=Madrigrano, Gina |author5=Stewart, Wendy |author6=Ahmed, A. G. |author7=Bradford, John |title=Sex Rôles in a Sample of Self-Identified BDSM Practitioners |publisher= |location= |year=2003 |pages=2 |isbn= |url=http://SexResearch.ca/SSSS/PDFs/IASR_2003_Fedoroff_Jacques.pdf |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=6 May 2012}} * TOKink conference, Toronto, Canada, 30 April 2006. Keynote.{{cite book |author=Jacques, Trevor |title=Who's on Top? (41MB) |publisher= |location= |year=2006 |pages=110 |isbn= |url=http://SexResearch.ca/SSSS/PDFs/TOKink2006.pdf |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=6 May 2012}} * 9th. [[International Conference on Bisexuality]], Toronto, Canada, 16 June 2006. Keynote.{{cite book |title=Kinky Colours, Sexy Spectra (40MB)|last=Jacques|first=Trevor H. |publisher= |location=Toronto |year=2006 |pages=131 |isbn= |url=http://SexResearch.ca/SSSS/PDFs/ICB9_2006.pdf |format=pdf |quote= |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=13 Dec 2013}} ==Media== * ''[[Too Much 4 Much]]'', CityTV (1992). Interview about [[Nine Inch Nails]]’ ''[[Happiness in Slavery]]'' * ''[[SexTV]]'',{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0818425/ |title= ''SexTV''|publisher=CityTV, SexTV |accessdate=7 May 2012}} season 1, episode 4, 7 November 1998. Feature interview about BDSM. * ''[[TVOntario]]'', (1999). Panel member following first showing of ''Tops and Bottoms''. * ''[[Sex Matters]]'',{{cite web |url=http://www.cp24.com/sexmatters/ |title= ''Sex Matters''|publisher=CP24 |accessdate=7 May 2012}} 26 February 2010. Interview about BDSM. == References and further reading == {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://TrevorJacques.com/ Official website] * [http://WholeSM.com/ WholeSM Publishing] * [http://ACToronto.org/ AIDS Committee of Toronto] * [http://ACToronto.org/bdsm/ BDSM pamphlet web page] * [http://SaferSM.org/ The Safer SM Education Project] {{BDSM}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jacques, Trevor H.}} [[Category:1956 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People educated at St Joseph's College, Ipswich]] [[Category:Alumni of Imperial College London]] [[Category:Alumni of the Royal College of Science]] [[Category:Canadian non-fiction writers]] [[Category:BDSM people]] [[Category:BDSM writers]] [[Category:BDSM activists]] [[Category:BDSM publishers]] [[Category:Sex educators]] [[Category:LGBT writers from Canada]] [[Category:Gay writers]] [[Category:LGBT people from England]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = Washington Conservation Guild | image = File:Washington_Conservation_Guild_logo.gif | established = {{Start date|1967}} | type = Professional conservation association | region_served = [[Washington Metropolitan Area]] | website = {{URL|http://washingtonconservationguild.org/}} }}
The '''Washington Conservation Guild''' (WCG) is a non-profit organization of conservation professionals. The WCG serves as a resource for learning about the care of art collections.
== History == The Washington Conservation Guild (WCG) is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization established in 1967 for professional conservators, students, and others interested in the preservation of art and historic materials.
The idea for the regional conservation group was proposed as early as 1965, when the International Council of Museums (ICOM)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://icom.museum/|title=ICOM - The International Council of Museums- ICOM|work=icom.museum}}</ref> Committee for Conservation met in Washington, DC.<ref name="auto">{{cite journal|journal=Washington Conservation Guild |title=Newsletter|date=September 2007|volume=31|issue=3}}</ref> The first steering committee met informally in the summer of 1967; here, it was decided that the primary intentions of the group was to provide a public forum where members could meet and "sponsor presentations to promote the exchange of ideas among conservators in all fields in the Washington area."<ref name="auto"/>
== Bylaws/Code of Ethics for Members == Bylaws or Code of Ethics put forward by the WCG to define its governance and for its members as a condition of membership.
== Organization & Governance ==
Based in [[Washington, D.C.]], the WCG draws its members primarily from Washington, Maryland, and northern Virginia. Members include both professional conservators and non-conservators - from government, state, and private museums; as well as studios, laboratories, and other cultural or academic organizations.<ref>{{cite web|title=Washington Conservation Guild|url=http://www.conservators-converse.org/2011/06/washington-conservation-guild/|accessdate=19 April 2014}}</ref> There are no restrictions on who may apply for membership.
The Washington Conservation Guild is governed by all-volunteered, membership-elected Board of Directors. The Board is composed of five officers and several directors. The WCG is also composed of several committees, led by Board-appointed chairs.
Elections for WCG Board Officers and Directors take place May at the Annual Business Meeting.
== Projects ==
===Events===
The WCG holds meetings from October through May each year, generally on the first Thursday of each month. Once annually, the Guild hosts the 3-Ring Circus event. The '3-Ring Circus' held January 9, 2014 in partnership with the National Museum of African Art, ran with three consecutive sessions.<ref>{{cite web|title=Washington Conservation Guild - 3 Ring Circus|url=https://www.iiconservation.org/node/4466|accessdate=23 April 2014}}</ref> The themes for the January 2014 3-Ring Circus were "Conservation in Far Flung Places;" "Analytical;" and "Contemporary."
The Guild also holds several monthly events over the course of the year. These events have included lectures, workshops, and networking sessions.
===Angels Project===
The Angels Project is designed to "promote a broader understanding of the importance of cultural preservation while providing meaningful assistance to important local collections."<ref>{{cite web|title=Angels |url=http://www.conservation-us.org/annual-meeting/angels-project|accessdate=19 April 2014}}</ref> Members participating in the Projects work pro-bono, volunteering their time and conservation expertise at a particular historic site. The Angels Project originally began in 1988 with the WCG's parent group, the American Institute of Conservation, pairing conservators with collections that need care.
===Fire at the Georgetown Public Library===
On April 30, 2007, a three-alarm fire caused significant damage to the Georgetown branch of the DC Public Library. City officials estimated the cost to repair the library at about $20 million; the renovation included the restoration of exterior doors and windows, stone masonry, and ornamental railings and grates.<ref>{{cite news|last=Klein|first=Allison|title=Investigators Pin the Blame On Paint-Removing Heat Gun|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=May 4, 2007}}</ref> Members of the WCG responded and coordinated with the DC library officials to set up disaster recovery efforts. At its annual meeting days later on May 3, 2007, the WCG held a fundraiser raffle. The proceeds went to support the conservation of the library's artwork, manuscripts, maps, and documents damaged in the fire.<ref>{{cite press release |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Washington Conservation Guild holds fundraiser for Georgetown Public Library|url=http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/blogs/citydesk/files/2007/05/0502gtown.pdf|format=PDF|work=Washington Conservation Guild|date=May 2, 2007|accessdate=2014-04-19}}</ref>
== Publications ==
The Washington Conservation Guild published a quarterly newsletter written and edited by volunteers to benefit guild members. Offered at first only as a printed edition, the newsletter transitioned to an online PDF. The newsletter was published as a PDF until December 2012, when it was replaced by a continuously-updated blog-style website. Archived newsletters<ref>{{cite web|url=http://washingtonconservationguild.org/newsletter-archive/|title=Newsletter archive|work=Washington Conservation Guild}}</ref> can be found on the WCG website.
In 2004, the Washington Conservation Guild published the second edition of its eBook, ''Conservation Resources for Art and Antiques''. ''Conservation Resources'' is a guide describing how to care for and preserve fine art, antiques, family heirlooms, memorabilia, and personal collections.
== See also == * [[Art conservation and restoration]] * [[Collections care]] * [[Conservation Associations and Professional Organizations]] * [[Conservation-restoration]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.conservation-us.org/annual-meeting/angels-project American Institute for Conservation of Historic and Artistic Works] * [http://icom.museum/ International Council of Museums] * [https://www.iiconservation.org/ International Institute for Conservation of Historic and Artistic Works]
